translation.en: [Sean Brock] I'm 39 years old,
and it's crazy to think that for this long,
all I've done is work in a kitchen.
translation.ko: 한 게 없다는 게 기가 막혀요

translation.en: All I've done is focus on being a great chef.
translation.ko: 훌륭한 셰프가 되는 것만 생각하고 살았죠

translation.en: That's a long road.
And that's... a lot of damage along the way.
And to be the chef that I am today wouldn't have happened
if I hadn't immersed myself in that level of workaholism.
translation.ko: 셰프로서 현재의 위치에 올 수 없었을 겁니다

translation.en: But...
it nearly killed me.
It literally... almost killed me.
[John T. Edge] The South has long been a beleaguered place, an insecure place.
It's a place wracked by guilt.
And those insecurities are informed by our peculiar and tragic-ass history.
translation.ko: 특이하고 비극적인 우리 역사가 그런 불안정함을 낳았어요

translation.en: And so, for the longest time,
Southerners didn't recognize the import of our food culture.
We swept the knowledge under the rug. We swept the people under the rug.
What Sean Brock did was say,
"The products and people of this place are of deep value,"
translation.ko: "존 에지 남부 식문화 연대" 이 지역 농산물과 사람들의 뛰어난 가치를 논하고

translation.en: and that, "this is the most important American cuisine one might interpret."
translation.ko: 세상에 선보여야 할 미국 요리라고 주장했어요

translation.en: That was bold.
[Adi Noe] Sean is one of the most obsessive people I've ever met.
translation.ko: 숀은 제가 만난 사람 중 가장 집착이 심해요

translation.en: He's obsessive about cars, music, folk art. He's all in.

translation.ko: 숀은 100%도 모자라 150%를 쏟는 사람이에요 "아디 노 숀의 여자 친구"

translation.en: If he's into it, it's an obsession.
[Tyler Brown] So much of Sean's food is story.
Whether it's his grandmother and her cornbread,
or seeking the origin of okra in Africa...
it all has roads that lead back to cooking.
translation.ko: 결국 원점인 요리로 되돌아와요 "타일러 브라운 셰프 겸 농부"

translation.en: [BJ Dennis] He's retracing the roots of Southern food:
translation.ko: 숀은 남부 음식의 뿌리를 거슬러 올라갑니다

translation.en: the Native American influence,
the French influence and the West African influence,
because he wants to tell the true story of Southern food.
translation.ko: 진짜 요리 이야기를 전하고자 하니까요 "BJ 데니스 걸라 기치 요리 전문가"

translation.en: [Edge] Sean has two flagship restaurants in Charleston:
one, McCrady's, which is this kind of elegant salon,
this place of luxury,
where you trust the chef to go on this magic carpet ride.
translation.ko: 셰프를 믿고 미지의 세계로 여행을 떠날 수 있죠

translation.en: His second restaurant,
Husk, is resolutely, unimpeachably, unapologetically Southern.
translation.ko: 허스크라고 하는데 모든 면에서 남부 그 자체죠

translation.en: It's fried pig ears. It's shucky beans. And it is not fussy.
translation.ko: 튀긴 돼지 귀, 셔키 빈스 등 겉치레가 없는 요리를 선보여요

translation.en: It is a place that harkens back to his grandma's table.
Sean can devote himself to doing ballotines of quail in one moment,
and devote himself to making the best damn chicken and dumplings in another moment.
translation.ko: 최고의 치킨 앤 덤플링을 뚝딱 내놓을 수 있는 셰프예요

translation.en: And that's one definition of genius,
to hold two seemingly opposing ideas in your head at the same time.
translation.ko: 대조적인 두 요리를 동시에 생각해낼 줄 알죠

translation.en: That's what his cooking shows.
But to understand Sean, you have to go back to his grandmother's kitchen.
translation.ko: 하지만 숀을 이해하려면 할머니의 주방을 알아야 해요

translation.en: You've gotta go back to the coalfields of Virginia.
[Brock] Most people have this idea of what Southern food is:
translation.ko: 남부 음식에 고정 관념을 가진 사람이 많아요

translation.en: being unhealthy, and greasy and calorie-heavy.
translation.ko: 건강에 안 좋고 기름진 고열량 음식으로 생각하죠

translation.en: But it's so much more than that.
It's amazing ingredients.
Unique ingredients.
It's specific varietals of plants and beans,
the preserves and the old traditions.
Taking humble ingredients and turning them into something truly extraordinary.
translation.ko: 소박한 재료를 써서 진귀한 요리를 선보이는 것

translation.en: That's what I see Southern food as.
translation.ko: 그게 제가 생각하는 남부 요리의 진수예요

translation.en: But, in the South, we've lost the seeds, the plants,
the stories.
And when we lose these plants, when we lose these breeds,
we lose multiple generations of wisdom.
We lose that connection to a culture, to a region and to a place.
translation.ko: 요리와 문화, 요리와 지역의 접점이 사라지게 되죠

translation.en: Once you realize that, you understand what a tragedy that is.
translation.ko: 그걸 인식하는 순간 큰 비극이란 걸 깨닫게 됩니다

translation.en: And if you have an opportunity to possibly help change that...
translation.ko: 내 힘이 현실을 바꾸는 데 보탬이 된다는 걸 알면

translation.en: that becomes your path. That becomes your journey,
translation.ko: 그 길을 마다할 수 없죠 내 사명으로 삼게 되고

translation.en: and, ultimately, you can make a small contribution to something that you love.
translation.ko: 그것이 제가 사랑하는 것에 조금이나마 기여하는 길이죠

translation.en: The mother of vinegar looks like a jellyfish.
[chef laughs] Kind of looks like liver.
[Brock laughing] Enter Sean's liver joke here.
I still have a jar of vinegar I made at McCrady's, at my house.
translation.ko: 맥크레이디스에서 만든 식초가 지금도 집에 있어요

translation.en: Yup. So that started with my grandma's mother,
which was probably 40 years old when I got it.
translation.ko: 내가 받았을 때 식초 나이가 마흔이었지

translation.en: It was always under the sink.
That was floating in there and it used to scare me to death.
translation.ko: 이런 게 둥둥 떠 있는데 무서워서 죽는 줄 알았어

translation.en: That was the first thing I grabbed after her funeral.
So, all those base vinegars that are at McCrady's are all my grandma's.
translation.ko: 맥크레이디스에서 쓰는 식초가 전부 할머니 씨초에서 나왔지

translation.en: So, we'll be able to keep that going and going.
I was born and raised in the Appalachian Mountains of Virginia,
translation.ko: 제가 나고 자란 곳은 버지니아 애팔래치아 산맥의

translation.en: deep in the coalfields.
I just remember, as a kid, playing in piles of coal all the time.
translation.ko: 어려서 늘 석탄 더미에서 놀던 기억이 나요

translation.en: My father grew up very, very, very poor.
When he was 11, he had to start working in the coalfields,
and that just shaped him into someone
who never wanted his kids to grow up poor, so he made sure of that.
translation.ko: 자식을 빈곤하게 키우지 않으려 최선을 다하셨습니다

translation.en: He never stopped working.
But he loved life. He really, really loved life.
translation.ko: 그래도 인생을 사랑하셨고 삶을 정말 즐기셨어요

translation.en: He ate steaks probably four nights a week.
He was always playing pranks and driving muscle cars really fast.
And we had an unbelievable childhood.
But when I was 11 years old, uh, my father passed away of a heart attack.
translation.ko: 하지만 아버지는 제가 11살 때 심장 마비로 돌아가셨어요

translation.en: He was 39 years old.
At that point, we didn't really have a choice.
We moved in with my grandmother.
My grandmother was constantly handling food.
translation.ko: 할머니는 요리를 손에서 놓지 않는 분이셨어요

translation.en: Huge, huge garden that was for survival.
If we ate something, we grew it or preserved it.
translation.ko: 우리가 직접 키우거나 저장한 음식을 먹었어요

translation.en: I grew up in that garden in the sun, in the dirt,
translation.ko: 전 밭에서 햇살과 흙에 파묻혀 자랐어요

translation.en: picking things and eating them while they're still alive and still vibrant.
translation.ko: 살아 숨 쉬는 농작물을 수확하고 먹었죠

translation.en: Food was this incredible source of pride.
My grandmother was constantly teaching me
the things that her grandparents taught her about food:
translation.ko: 음식에 관한 지식을 꾸준히 전수해 주셨습니다

translation.en: how to know when potatoes are ready to pull out of the ground,
translation.ko: 감자를 뽑아야 할 시기를 판단하는 법

translation.en: how to pick beans when they're ready,
how to snap a bean and string it at lightning speed.
translation.ko: 콩을 따고 재빨리 심을 제거하는 법

translation.en: That was just how I grew up.
My vault of deliciousness will always be there,
translation.ko: 제 맛의 기준은 언제나 그 자리에 있고

translation.en: and it was formed during that period of my life.
I remember bein' a kid and, uh...
All of the neighbors around, everybody had a different greasy bean.
translation.ko: 집마다 재배하는 그리시 빈이 조금씩 달랐어요

translation.en: And there would be this competition every year, who...
how many bushels you grew.
[man] It was a matter of pride.
And you think every single holler, every single family had unique beans,
corn, tomatoes, squash, everything.
That's a pretty color that you get on that pod there.
So many of these things, as you've noticed over the years, I'm sure,
translation.ko: 아마 오래 봐와서 알고 있을 테지만

translation.en: take on different names. The most common is the family name.
translation.ko: 저마다 이름이 달라요 주로 성씨를 많이 쓰죠

translation.en: This one came from Washington Parish, Louisiana,
grown for years by the Jones family, so they refer to it as the Jones pea.
translation.ko: 존스 가족이 오래 키운 거라 존스 콩이라고 불러요

translation.en: It's actually gray crowder.
I've told guests many times, who've come down to the shed...
translation.ko: 헛간까지 온 손님들께는 여러 번 설명해드려요

translation.en: We're talkin' about peas, beans, butter beans, you name it.
translation.ko: 완두콩, 일반 콩, 리마콩 등 종류가 다양하죠

translation.en: After a while, you'd, uh, look at that and you'd say,
"Yeah, I see that. What else you got to offer?"
It's not till you put that living history with it, the story with it.
translation.ko: 그러면 각 콩에 담긴 역사와 이야기를 해줘요

translation.en: You've got a chain this long, with no links missing, all...
passed down to today and all that history that went in between.
[Brock] Remind me what this is.
[man] It's, uh, Jimson weed.
One of my friends, uh, ate it and then ate a whole bag of dog food.
translation.ko: 친구 하나가 이걸 먹더니 개 사료 한 포대를 다 먹었죠

translation.en: -Ate a whole... -[both laughing]
[man] Ate a whole bag of dog--
-I gotta remember that. -[Brock continues laughing]
-Oh, man... [laughs] -Ate a whole bag of dog food?
Living in the country, you gotta find some way to have fun.
[Brock] At the age of 15, we moved
to a larger town in Virginia, called Abingdon,
translation.ko: 버지니아의 좀 더 큰 도시 애빙던으로 갔어요

translation.en: and that's when I got my first restaurant job.
First day I walked into that kitchen, it was not what I was expecting.
translation.ko: 첫날 주방에 들어갔는데 제 상상과는 달랐어요

translation.en: It was the scariest, craziest thing I'd ever seen.
translation.ko: 그렇게 무섭고 정신없는 꼴은 생전 처음 봤어요

translation.en: Heavy metal playing so loud...
Tickets waving in the wind...
There was a smoking table in the kitchen.
And all of these people moving so quickly, and screaming and yelling,
translation.ko: 모두 너무나 빨리 움직이면서 고함치고 소리 질렀어요

translation.en: and talking about how much whisky they drank the night before.
translation.ko: 전날 밤에 위스키를 얼마나 마셨는지 떠드는데

translation.en: It was like a pirate ship.
And I remember, the first few nights, being splashed with hot oil,
and just burns everywhere.
And people seeing my arms and thinking I'd been abused.
translation.ko: 사람들이 제 팔을 보면 어디서 맞고 다니는 줄 알았죠

translation.en: And I would say with pride, "[stutters] Oh, I'm a chef. I'm a cook."
I was hooked immediately.
[Brock] After high school, I knew that I wanted to be a chef,
and so I started looking into the best culinary cities in America.
translation.ko: 미국 최고의 미식 도시가 어디인지 찾기 시작했죠

translation.en: Charleston was the closest, so I packed up and moved to Charleston.
translation.ko: 찰스턴이 가장 가까워서 짐을 싸서 이사했습니다

translation.en: [Edge] If you think about restaurant cities in the American South,
translation.ko: 맛집으로 유명한 미국 남부 도시를 생각하면

translation.en: the most storied cuisine emanates from Charleston.
translation.ko: 가장 유명한 요리를 내놓는 곳이 찰스턴이죠

translation.en: And Sean arrives like a tourist, almost.
This kind of wild-eyed kid, who was so excited, just curious.
translation.ko: 기대와 호기심이 가득했던 꿈 많은 아이였죠

translation.en: It was such a culture shock for me.
It might as well have been Japanese food to an Appalachian guy.
translation.ko: 애팔래치아 청년에게는 일본 음식만큼 낯선 요리였죠

translation.en: I had never ever stepped foot
in any restaurant as nice as the ones are here.
To see a kitchen full of professional chefs,
turning out these gorgeous plates of food...
it was exhilarating.
At that time, the chefs doing fine dining in Charleston
translation.ko: 당시 찰스턴에서 파인 다이닝을 하던 셰프들은

translation.en: were taking these iconic and classic dishes,
translation.ko: 남부를 상징하는 전통 요리를 소재로 삼았어요

translation.en: like Hoppin' John, and shrimp and grits,
and cleaning them up, making them beautiful.
I wanted to learn how to do that.
So, I threw myself into the craft of cooking.
[chef 1] Want to eat a palmetto tree?
[chef 2] It smells pretty good.
-Cook something directly on here? -[sniffs]
[Brock] Ah! We cook rice in this!
Yeah, and it'll seal. So, we could put rice in this, seal it off and throw it in the fire.
translation.ko: 쌀을 넣고 밀봉해서 불에 넣으면 돼

translation.en: It definitely gets super fibrous at the end--
That's edible.
-It's delicious! -[chef 2] It is. It's delicious.
-[chef 3] That's so good. -[sniffs]
Sean and I met in 1997 at Peninsula Grill in Charleston, South Carolina.
translation.ko: 숀과 저는 1997년에 찰스턴에 있는 페닌술라 그릴에서 만났어요

translation.en: First impression of Sean was how serious he was about being a chef.
translation.ko: 진지하게 셰프의 꿈을 키워간다는 인상을 받았죠

translation.en: Sean worked at Peninsula Grill, went to school,
translation.ko: 숀은 페닌술라 그릴에서 일하며 학교에 다녔고

translation.en: and, on his days off, he worked at another restaurant.
I remember asking him, "Don't you need a day off?"
He's like, "No, all I wanna do is work."
[Brock] I was insane about learning, about trying to master my craft,
translation.ko: 저는 배움에 미쳐 있었고 요리를 터득하고 싶었어요

translation.en: trying to make the knife cuts perfect, the sauces perfect.
That was my source of pride.
But when I discovered modern cooking, that changed everything.
translation.ko: 하지만 현대 요리를 접하게 되면서 모든 게 바뀌었습니다

translation.en: Yeah, it's translucent, it's beautiful...
[Brock] The idea that I could manipulate ingredients
into this magical experience. That was incredible to me.
translation.ko: 마법 같은 경험을 창조하는 건 경이로운 일이었어요

translation.en: No one was cooking Southern food that way.
translation.ko: 남부에는 그런 식으로 요리하는 사람이 없었기에

translation.en: And so modern cooking became my new obsession.
[Edge] I remember the first time I heard about Sean.
translation.ko: 숀 얘기를 처음 들었을 때가 기억나요

translation.en: He was a molecular wunderkind,
this kind of experimental chef, doing ham-fat cotton candy.
translation.ko: 햄 지방 솜사탕 같은 실험적인 요리를 하는 셰프였죠

translation.en: Playful, inventive food that surprised.
I saw him one time with some barbeque sandwiches
and liquid nitrogen.
And he had been steeping the sandwiches in milk,
and then slowly began to make, on the back of his pickup truck,
translation.ko: 서서히 새로운 요리를 만들었죠 픽업트럭 뒷자리에서

translation.en: while drinking whisky from a bottle...
He began to plunk out little pellets of barbecue ice cream.
translation.ko: 작은 알갱이로 된 바비큐 아이스크림을 만들었습니다

translation.en: And I saw, in that moment, kind of the beginnings of Sean.
translation.ko: 저는 그 순간 숀의 시작을 목격했어요

translation.en: He was the guy on a path to figure out who he is and what he wants to cook.
translation.ko: 숀은 자신의 정체성과 요리 철학을 찾아 나섰어요

translation.en: [chef] Grab the nicest one.
[Brock] Yes.
Will you grab a flower?
[Brock] The first time I was hired as the head chef of a restaurant
was at the Hermitage Hotel, Nashville, Tennessee.
And I was 24, and it was the first time I'd really had the freedom
translation.ko: 전 24살이었고 그때 처음으로 제가 정말 원하는 요리를 만들 자유를 얻었죠

translation.en: to create my own plate of food.
translation.ko: 제가 정말 원하는 요리를 만들 자유를 얻었죠

translation.en: My own menu. My own vision.
translation.ko: 제가 짠 메뉴에 제 비전을 담아

translation.en: I could do whatever I wanted.
I was so excited to show off.
translation.ko: 실력을 뽐낼 수 있다는 게 너무나 신났어요

translation.en: And so, when we opened the restaurant, our tasting menu was 30 courses.
I had this idea that modern Southern food could be this amazing thing.
translation.ko: 현대식 남부 요리는 환상적이란 믿음이 있었죠

translation.en: We opened on Valentine's Day.
We booked 275 guests,
and I think we fed about 50 people.
To be standing in the middle of that kitchen,
watching food just be overcooked and thrown in the garbage,
and food coming back, and...
the people who hired me to do that job standing there just like...
translation.ko: 저를 고용한 사람들은 그저 이러고 서 있었죠

translation.en: "We made a mistake."
That feeling was terrible. I mean, it was just terrible.
A few days later, the review comes out.
I felt such guilt and shame.
I've never ever wanted to quit something so bad in my entire life.
translation.ko: 제 인생에 그렇게 달아나고 싶었던 적이 없었어요

translation.en: But instead, I walked in the next day and I apologized,
and I said,
"I'm not gonna take another day off until we get a good review."
translation.ko: '좋은 비평이 나올 때까지 하루도 쉬지 않겠습니다'

translation.en: I was determined to figure out how to execute my vision
translation.ko: 제 비전을 실현할 방법을 찾아 직책에 걸맞은 사람이란 걸

translation.en: to prove myself worthy of that job.
I worked for ten months straight, every day.
I didn't leave the kitchen.
I slept under tables with mops as pillows, and I was living in the kitchen.
translation.ko: 걸레를 베개 삼아 자면서 주방에서 살았습니다

translation.en: Perfectionism was all I cared about.
Every single aspect of every single thing had to be done my way,
translation.ko: 어느 하나라도 처음부터 끝까지 제 방식만 고수했고

translation.en: and I wasn't very nice about it.
I would get so mad when people wanted to take days off.
translation.ko: 누가 쉬겠다고 하면 미친 듯이 화를 냈어요

translation.en: I couldn't understand why no one else cared as much as I cared.
translation.ko: 왜 나처럼 헌신하지 않는지 이해할 수가 없었어요

translation.en: It's important to watch the color of the smoke.
translation.ko: 연기 색깔을 주의 깊게 봐야 해

translation.en: Pretty much the entire kitchen staff quit.
But I couldn't fail.
I couldn't fail.
Ten months later, the paper in Nashville came back to the restaurant.
translation.ko: 열 달 후, 내슈빌 신문에서 다시 가게를 찾았습니다

translation.en: And so, I sat outside of the place where the papers were being printed,
translation.ko: 저는 신문 인쇄소 앞에서 새벽 4~5시까지 앉아

translation.en: until 4:00 or 5:00 in the morning.
That ten months of extreme workaholism...
translation.ko: 극도의 일 중독자로 살았던 그 열 달이

translation.en: It worked.
And so that was the way I worked.
That was the way I thought.
That was the way I expected everyone else to feel.
translation.ko: 모든 이가 그렇게 느끼기를 바라게 됐어요

translation.en: What's up, Mother hog?
Can't believe there's still greenage. [chuckles] [Brock] Right?
-I got this pig from John Foltz. -[Brock chuckles]
[farmer] Alabama is her name. She's an iron-age pig.
It's, uh... basically an Ossabaw crossed with a Meishan
and some other mixes. Carl Blake, out of...
translation.ko: 다른 종이 더 섞였죠 칼 블레이크라고

translation.en: out of, uh, Iowa, was doin 'em.
What an amazing creature.
-Four hundred years, it's been here. -[farmer] Right?
[Brock] What'll you do with the Hereford?
I'm just using it to cross with our Ossabaws.
People are so used to pink, white pork. Big, fat portions.
translation.ko: 사람들은 지방이 없는 분홍이나 흰 돼지만 찾아요

translation.en: No fat.
No inner muscular fat.
You can't take a grocery store pork chop
and cook it in a skillet now without burning the shit out of it.
Whereas, you took a heritage-breed hog pork chop, uh...
translation.ko: 근데 헤리티지 품종의 호그 돼지 갈비는

translation.en: throw it in there and just add salt and pepper,
translation.ko: 소금, 후추 외에 다른 건 필요 없어요

translation.en: its own fat.
I worked on this breed for years
and we ended up calling it "Berkawata-Derokaball"
Everybody that raises pigs thinks they're gonna create a "super pig."
translation.ko: 돼지 키우는 사람은 누구나 슈퍼 돼지를 키워낼 꿈을 꿔요

translation.en: Yeah, I was trying to do that.
Yeah, I've met ten pig friend farmers on Facebook and all the social medias,
translation.ko: 페이스북과 SNS에서 만난 돼지 사육자 친구 10명이

translation.en: and they've all got the "super pig." You know?
So, it's really... That is pretty comical.
This brings back a lot of memory
of running through all this, chasing pigs for the hell of it.
translation.ko: 돼지를 쫓던 옛 기억이 그대로 되살아나네요

translation.en: [farmer] Right? Time flies.
[Brock] After three years at the Hermitage Hotel, I started wondering about the next step.
translation.ko: 허미티지 호텔에서 3년 일하고 앞날을 고민하기 시작했어요

translation.en: When an opportunity came up to be the chef at McCrady's,
the best restaurant in Charleston,
I was so excited to show off my vision of modern Southern food to this city.
translation.ko: 현대식 남부 요리를 선보일 꿈을 펼칠 수 있다는 게 기뻤죠

translation.en: But when I arrived, I was frustrated with the produce that was available.
translation.ko: 하지만 막상 와 보니 그곳의 식자재가 실망스러웠어요

translation.en: The varietals that I wanted.
The quality that I wanted.
I was trying to push this cuisine into the future.
And that can't happen if the ingredients don't exist.
And that's when I met Glenn Roberts,
the seedsman who was restoring the pantry of the Lowcountry.
[Roberts] Here, we have 4,000-year-old different rices from Africa.
translation.ko: 4천 년 된 아프리카의 여러 벼 품종을 심었어요

translation.en: They're salt-tolerant, water-tolerant, disease-tolerant and they're fast.
translation.ko: 염분, 물, 질병 내성이 강하고 빨리 자라죠

translation.en: Wicked fast.
-See the milk? -[Brock] Wow. Did you see that?
[Roberts] Yeah. Try that one.
-It, like, exploded milk. -[Roberts] Yeah.
-[man] It's awesome, isn't it? -Wow!
[Roberts] And you can take the leaves, juice them, and then dye the rice kernels.
translation.ko: 잎도 따다가 즙을 짜서 쌀알을 물들일 수 있어요

translation.en: [Brock] That's really cool.
Glenn knew that in order to revive the cuisine of the Lowcountry,
you have to start with the specific varietals of the Carolina rice kitchen.
translation.ko: 캐롤라이나 벼 품종부터 복원해야 한다고 믿었어요

translation.en: [Dennis] To understand Charleston cuisine,
you have to understand its roots, which is based in West Africa.
translation.ko: 이 요리의 뿌리를 알아야 하는데 원점은 서아프리카예요

translation.en: It's a very layered cuisine, heavily influenced by rice,
translation.ko: 매우 다층적인 요리로 쌀의 영향력이 아주 큽니다

translation.en: because obviously rice made a lot of people in the city rich
translation.ko: 쌀에 대해 잘 알았던 서아프리카 노예들 덕에

translation.en: through the knowledge of enslaved West Africans.
Those who were enslaved brought their knowledge of rice culture,
translation.ko: 노예로 잡혀 온 이들이 쌀 문화에 대한 지식을 전수했고

translation.en: the okra, the greens,
these different vegetables that we see on that Southern table.
translation.ko: 남부 요리에만 등장하는 색다른 채소들을 알렸죠

translation.en: [Edge] All these crops of West African origin or West African expertise
translation.ko: 서아프리카가 원산지이거나 그쪽 지식으로 재배한 곡물이

translation.en: are what made dishes that are dependent upon rice for their backbone,
like Hoppin' John, like Limpin' Susan, so specific to Charleston.
translation.ko: 호핑 존, 림핑 수전 같은 찰스턴 향토 요리로 탄생했어요

translation.en: But we lost these ingredients after the Civil War,
translation.ko: 하지만 남북전쟁 이후 그런 재료가 사라졌죠

translation.en: when people of West African descent quit the rice fields for jobs in the city,
translation.ko: 서아프리카계 후손은 벼농사를 접고 도시로 가거나

translation.en: or moved the hell out of South Carolina and went to Philadelphia and New York.
And that's justice.
Right? That's progress.
And yet...
if you value the agricultural knowledge that West African peoples brought,
translation.ko: 서아프리카계 사람들이 가져온 농업 지식의 가치가

translation.en: and then nurtured in the American South, in the Lowcountry...
translation.ko: 남부 로컨트리에서 꽃 피웠던 점을 생각하면

translation.en: you do lament that loss of knowledge.
You do lament that loss of beauty in those rice kitchen dishes.
translation.ko: 쌀 요리의 매력이 사라진 것도 비통합니다

translation.en: It's complicated. Like everything about the South, it's complicated.
translation.ko: 복잡한 얘기예요 남부와 관련되면 다 복잡하죠

translation.en: [man] What do you usually roast it in?
[Brock] My favorite way is roasted in a cast iron pan with a little lard.
translation.ko: 주물 팬에 라드를 약간 넣어 로스트하는 걸

translation.en: -That's it. [chuckles] -Lard's the best.
[Brock] That's how you can convert okra haters.
-Smells like roasted okra. -[chef] Yeah.
[Brock] I had to be a part of putting these varietals that were nearly extinct
back into production, back on to the plate.
Yeah. Unbelievable. Shit, that's good.
I was going from farm to farm to farm.
"These are the seeds we have to grow.
Plant. Plant. Plant. I'll buy everything. I'll buy it all."
translation.ko: '무조건 심으세요, 제가 다 살게요 전부 사겠습니다'

translation.en: And, little by little, our pantry was being stocked with ingredients
translation.ko: 아주 조금씩 이 지역 토속 품종이

translation.en: that were unique and true to this place.
And I was able to push this cuisine forward.
And the food got crazier and crazier, and, for me, more fun.
translation.ko: 제 요리는 점점 더 과감해졌고 즐거움도 늘었습니다

translation.en: All of a sudden, the restaurant's gaining a lot of attention.
translation.ko: 갑자기 우리 레스토랑에 많은 관심이 쏟아졌어요

translation.en: People were traveling from outside of Charleston
to come see what was happening at McCrady's.
In 2010, I got nominated
for the James Beard Award for, uh, Best Chef: Southeast.
And I won.
I had shown to the world that modern Southern food could be amazing.
translation.ko: 현대 남부 요리가 멋지다는 걸 세상에 보여줬죠

translation.en: At McCrady's, I was so focused
on creativity and being different,
I thought I had to be in the kitchen all the time.
translation.ko: 전 주방을 떠나면 절대 안 되는 줄 알았어요

translation.en: But I kept hearing these romantic stories from farmers about seed saving
translation.ko: 하지만 종자를 지키는 농부들과 그들의 긍지에 관한

translation.en: and the pride that came along with that.
I had to experience that for myself.
And so, I found a plot of dirt,
begged Glenn for seeds.
He gave me a few ears
of this beautiful, super dark, almost black-red corn
translation.ko: 거의 암적색에 가까운 아름다운 옥수수 이삭이었죠

translation.en: that was almost extinct, called Jimmy Red Corn.
translation.ko: 멸종 직전의 지미 레드 콘이란 품종이었어요

translation.en: And every day I would wake up at 6:00 and just work on the garden.
Being back in the sun, watching that corn grow,
translation.ko: 다시 햇살로 나가 자라는 옥수수를 보고

translation.en: taking care of it, worrying about it
was a part of the puzzle that'd been missing since I was a kid.
translation.ko: 성인이 되고 잃어버렸던 퍼즐 한 조각이 맞춰졌어요

translation.en: And I fell in love with dirt again.
That first pan of cornbread I made
translation.ko: 제 옥수수로 만든 첫 번째 콘브레드는

translation.en: felt just like eating at my grandmother's table.
And it just came full circle.
I knew what I needed to do and what path I needed to take.
translation.ko: 내가 해야 할 일과 가야 할 길을 깨달았어요

translation.en: And a few months later, we opened Husk.
translation.ko: 그리고 몇 달 후에 허스크를 열었습니다

translation.en: At Husk, our mission
was to celebrate simple, soulful Southern recipes and traditions,
translation.ko: 할머니가 해주시던 소박하고 진솔한 남부 요리의

translation.en: just like my grandmother did.
The defining principle at Husk since its inception has been,
"If it's not Southern, it's not walking in the door."
[Brock] When you can't just pick up the phone
and order balsamic vinegar from Italy and olive oil from Spain,
translation.ko: 이탈리아 발사믹 식초와 스페인 올리브유를 시키지 않고

translation.en: you make your own.
You study the traditions.
And so we started making our own vinegars and oils and salts
translation.ko: 우리만의 식초와 기름과 소금을 만들기 시작했고

translation.en: and grinding our own flours.
And it was so much better than anything we ever cooked with.
translation.ko: 그간 우리가 썼던 어떤 재료보다도 훌륭했어요

translation.en: We became collectors, scouting the South for ingredients.
translation.ko: 우리는 수집가가 됐고 재료를 찾아 남부를 누볐습니다

translation.en: It felt we were doing something that had meaning.
translation.ko: 의미 있는 일을 한다는 기분이 들었어요

translation.en: It felt like it needed to be done.
And I ate it up. I couldn't get enough of it.
[Edge] There's this rediscovery of Southern food that's pinned to Sean.
He helped revive.
He helped to re-frame.
He helped us see again the value of these foods.
That vote of confidence for the South meant a lot
when Sean shouted it through his megaphone.
[Brock] And not long after we opened Husk in Charleston,
translation.ko: "호핑 존과 메기" 찰스턴에 허스크를 열고 얼마 안 돼서

translation.en: Bon Appétit named us the best new restaurant in America.
translation.ko: '본 아페티'에 미국 최고의 신규 레스토랑으로 뽑혔어요

translation.en: That's when everything took off.
Life was moving a thousand miles an hour.
I was running back and forth between Husk and McCrady's,
cooking for 500 people a day.
People were paying attention to Southern food,
becoming interested on a different level. It was exhilarating.
In a two-year period, I opened four restaurants.
At that point of my life was a lot of running around.
Cameras in my face and every word printed.
translation.ko: 늘 카메라가 따라붙었고 하는 말마다 보도됐어요

translation.en: My role as a chef in the South had grown.
I was representing a cuisine and a culture.
translation.ko: 남부 요리와 문화를 대표하는 사람이 되니

translation.en: That's an enormous amount of pressure.
And so, I just worked harder.
One day, I woke up and stood up out of bed,
translation.ko: 어느 날 아침에 일어나 침대에서 빠져나오니

translation.en: and it felt like the room was spinning.
I'd lost my balance. I had to sit back down.
And when I opened my eyes again, uh, I couldn't focus my vision.
translation.ko: 다시 눈을 떴는데 초점이 안 맞았습니다

translation.en: I was seeing double.
I couldn't do anything.
The first time in my entire career, I didn't wake up and go straight to work.
translation.ko: 요리를 시작하고 처음으로 눈 뜨자마자 출근하지 못했어요

translation.en: I was helpless.
But all the doctors I saw were just stumped.
They couldn't understand what was going on.
That's when the surgeries began.
A spoon popped into my eyeballs while I'm awake,
hearing and smelling and feeling them cutting away at my eyelids,
translation.ko: 눈꺼풀 절개하는 소리, 냄새, 느낌이 생생했어요

translation.en: lying on the couch with ice pads on my eyes
translation.ko: 눈에 얼음을 대고 소파에 누워 있는데

translation.en: and blood dripping down my face.
I had six surgeries total,
and the double vision and droopy eyelids just kept coming back.
translation.ko: 물체가 둘로 보이고 눈꺼풀이 내려앉긴 마찬가지였죠

translation.en: It was like a horror movie.
And this is keeping me from working.
And that was making me crazy.
I just became so angry at the world.
I was so frustrated and scared to death,
just thinking, "Am I never gonna be able to cook again?"
And the only coping mechanism I had to equalize or to numb
translation.ko: 저를 잠자코 있게 하는 유일한 위로는

translation.en: was a garage full of bourbon.
I didn't know what to do. What am I supposed to do?
translation.ko: 전 어쩔 줄을 몰랐습니다 뭘 할 수 있겠어요?

translation.en: -[woman] Hey, Sean, how are you? -[Brock] Hey. Great.
[woman] Come on back.
Good, good, good. Take a look at my nose.
[Brock] Almost two years passed, not working,
just miserable, until I finally flew to the Mayo Clinic.
We did a number of tests,
and the neurologist says,
"This...
sounds and seems like myasthenia gravis,
the really rare disease that affects neuro-muscular communication."
This disease is exacerbated by stress and fatigue.
There's no cure for this
other than controlling stress, controlling anxiety.
But to treat the symptoms, the doctor gave me a bunch of pills,
translation.ko: 하지만 증세 완화를 위해 약을 잔뜩 처방해줬어요

translation.en: and I immediately started feeling better.
My vision was perfect.
My eyelids were perfect. I felt like Superman.
To be able to use a knife again was such an amazing feeling.
I had a year and a half of ideas pent up,
a year and a half of dishes swimming around in my head.
So, I just started cooking like crazy
and being back in the kitchen was incredible.
translation.ko: 다시 주방에 있다는 게 믿기지 않았어요

translation.en: [Noe] He basically dove back in full force and beyond full force,
in, just, this desperation to make up for lost time.
But he was on something like 16 mg of prednisone,
and that can make anyone feel like Superman.
[Brock] I thought I had everything under control,
and then, one day, I was driving to work,
and my vision just snapped and went straight into double vision.
The pills had stopped working,
and, the next day, my doctor told me
the myasthenia was graduating from my eyes into full-body myasthenia.
And that was really bad news,
because, when that happens, the future is living with tubes down your throat.
translation.ko: 그렇게 되면 목구멍에 관을 달고 살아야 해요

translation.en: And, uh...
I, um, just hit a level of depression
that, uh, I'd never experienced before,
and I drowned my pain in bourbon.
I was in the depths of misery at that point.
translation.ko: 그 시절의 저는 절망의 늪에 빠져 있었죠

translation.en: I stopped caring. I just gave up.
He wasn't himself. He had a vacant look in his eye.
He was beyond just needing to see a therapist.
[Edge] There was a darkness about him.
He was grappling with stuff I didn't understand.
translation.ko: 제가 이해할 수 없는 전쟁을 치르고 있었죠

translation.en: There was something missing there, like... He needed help.
That was, uh... He was crying out for help.
[Brock] I remember I was upstairs and my doorbell rang.
I opened the door and there were three people standing there
that weren't supposed to be standing there...
three people standing there that I respect.
translation.ko: 제가 존경하는 세 사람이 서 있더군요

translation.en: They were trembling, full-body trembles.
translation.ko: 세 사람은 떨고 있었어요 온몸을 떨었죠

translation.en: I knew exactly what was happening.
And I...
felt this amazing, uh, relief, to be quite honest.
It was almost like... like the, the help had arrived.
And, uh...
we all sit down at a table to have an intervention,
translation.ko: 다 같이 탁자에 앉아 대화를 나눴어요

translation.en: and I remember saying, "You can do whatever you want.
translation.ko: 그런 말이 기억나네요 '다들 하고 싶은 대로 해'

translation.en: You can read whatever you want, but I am going.
I will go right now."
Thirty-nine, I am. Thirty-nine years old.
The same age my father was when he passed away.
I nearly broke myself, trying to save Southern food,
translation.ko: 남부 음식을 지키려다가 벼랑 끝까지 갔지만

translation.en: but you can't save anything when you're dead.
When I got to rehab, I didn't have work and whisky to hide behind.
translation.ko: 재활원에 가니까 술과 일 뒤에 숨을 수 없었어요

translation.en: I had to face the person in the mirror.
I realized that my desire to always be at work is exactly how my father was.
translation.ko: 일을 놓지 못하던 아버지와 똑같았다는 걸 깨달았어요

translation.en: The moment that I knew it didn't have to be that way anymore was unbelievable.
translation.ko: 그렇게 살지 않아도 된다는 걸 의외의 순간에 깨달았어요

translation.en: I was standing in the grass,
admiring the sky, and how green the grass was,
and I could hear the birds again, and I was like,
I'm awake."
I saw that connection between taking care of myself,
and how that affects my disease, which affects my happiness.
My vision was fine.
My muscles were fine.
It was such an amazing feeling.
But the new perspective that I have takes...
an enormous amount of work every day.
To slow down...
That's difficult for me.
[whistles] Dakota, refill.
[Brock] And if I skip self-care,
I feel the old Sean creeping back in.
He'll be there for a long time,
in the parking lot, doing push-ups, waiting for that moment.
-How long you gonna let this one go? -Two months.
-Yeah, that's alcohol. Whoo! -Yeah.
-Hello, old friend. -[both laugh]
Now the trick is to keep that edge,
to keep that passion, to keep that intensity
while taking care of myself.
Now my goal is happiness,
and the food that is created now is the best food I've ever cooked.
translation.ko: 요즘은 그 어느 때보다 좋은 요리를 만들고 있어요

translation.en: [man] When I was a kid, the triggerfish was actually shack money.
translation.ko: 내가 어렸을 때 쥐치 종류는 버리는 고기였죠

translation.en: If they only knew now what they were missing.
[Roberts] Carolina Gold Rice was here prior to 1863.
-[Brock] It's like a time vault. -[Roberts] It's like a time capsule.
translation.ko: - 이게 역사의 보고군요 - 타임캡슐 같은 곳이죠

translation.en: Exactly.
[man] Nice.
That'll be delicious with a little butter.
[Brock] This corn is just like me.
It started in Appalachia and ended up in the Lowcountry.
[man] Audrey Morgan's bean.
[Brock] I know these.
I'll never forget that time I brought my mom here.
-We were doin' a talk. -We were doin' that talk, and then, uh...
-That brought her to tears-- -I looked over, and my mom was crying.
I was like, "Uh, what just happened?" And then I saw...
What did I say? [laughing]
...my grandma's name sittin' there.
-That's the power of it all. -[laughs] I know it. It is.
[Brock] Someday, I hope to see these on menus all over the South.
translation.ko: 언젠가 이 콩으로 만든 요리가 남부 전역에 퍼지길 바라요

translation.en: [man] Wouldn't that be something?
[Brock] The thought of these being served in restaurants all over the South
translation.ko: 남부 전역의 식당에서 이 콩을 요리해서 낼 때마다

translation.en: and my grandma's name being mentioned every time...
translation.ko: 남부 전역의 식당에서 이 콩을 요리해서 낼 때마다 할머니 이름이 회자된다고 생각하면...

translation.en: [stutters] That's legacy. That's her life.
That was her passion, these things.
